* 21 April: The UAE Cabinet has approved a draft law on national safety to guarantee the protection of society in cases of disasters and any healthcare, economic and environmental threats to the country.

* 13 April: The Ministry of Economy has announced a new list of electronic service fees, reflecting a reduction across 94 of its offered services, particularly provided by the Ministry to the public covering individuals, companies and the business sector.

* 5 April: An additional AED 156 billion stimulus plan announced : an AED 95 billion liquidity buffer relief and an AED 61 billion reduction of cash reserves requirements

* 22 March: UAE Cabinet approves additional AED16 billion stimulus package

* The Central Bank of the UAE announced on 15 March an AED 100 billion comprehensive Economic Support Scheme for retail and corporate customers affected by COVID-19. These measures included the approval of loan eligibility, reduction of capital and the adoption of new policies. The Economic Support Scheme consists of:
1. A financial support plan which includes AED 50 billion from the CBUAE funds through collateralized loans at zero cost to all borrowing banks operating in the UAE and AED 50 billion funds freed up from banks' capital buffers
2. Allowing banks to free-up their regulatory capital buffers to boost lending capacity and support the UAE economy.
3. All Banks operating in the UAE will have access to loans and advances extended at zero cost against collateral by the CBUAE.
4. Banks to defer due payments for a period of 6 months to their corporate and individual clients
5. The CBUAE confirms that the foreign currency reserves which amount to AED 405 billion is adequate to safeguard the stability of the national currency and achieve monetary and financial stability in the State.
6. Banks to grant temporary relief from the payments of principal and interest on outstanding loans for all affected private sector companies and retail customers in the UAE
7. Adopting new systems to reduce fees incurred by merchants when their customers pay by debit or credit cards
8. Approving new regulations to set limits on fees imposed by banks on small and medium enterprises, and stipulate that banks cannot demand a minimum account balance exceeding AED 10,000

* 12 March: Dubai Government launched an AED 1.5 billion economic stimulus package
column25:
* 14 June: UAE Cabinet approves bonuses for emergency workers

* 1 June: DHA establishes new medical isolation facility for COVID-19 patients

* 31 May: Department of Health provides free COVID-19 testing in high-density areas in Abu Dhabi

* 29 May: The Ministry of Health and Prevention, the Ministry of Interior, and the National Emergency Crisis and Disasters Management Authority announced that the National Disinfection Programme will be conducted from 10 PM to 6 AM instead of 8 PM to 6 AM, effective from Saturday, 30th May

* 24 May: The UAE Government announced that its regular media briefing on the latest COVID-19 developments and the country's ongoing preventive measures to contain the spread of the virus will resume from Monday, May 25
*20 May: All private health facilities in Dubai will be able to resume most of their alternative medical therapies with immediate effect, except for dental and ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat) services which continue to fall in the essential or emergency category only.

* 19 May: The UAE National Programme for Happiness and Wellbeing has announced the launch of a mental health hotline to support individuals' mental health and psychological wellbeing during the coronavirus pandemic. The hotline, titled 'Mental Support Line', aims to provide initial psychological counselling and support to community members, via the cooperation of volunteer mental health experts, consultants and specialists.

* 15 May: Dubai Health Authority deploys advanced mobile testing unit to conduct COVID-19 screening in labour camps.

* 13 May: Teams from the PCE distributed 30,000 masks, produced by inmates as part of the Interior ministry's rehabilitation programmes, to the workers in industrial areas.
*13 May: The Abu Dhabi Emergency Crisis and Disasters Committee for COVID-19 Pandemic has inaugurated a field hospital at Al Razeen as part of Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan's field hospital initiative. In addition to Razeen field hospital, the committee is working on 4 further field hospitals.
*10 May: The Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear administration of the Abu Dhabi Police has carried out the disinfection of 48,383 ambulances and non-emergency vehicles transporting COVID-19 patients.

* 7 May: The Ministry of Health and Prevention has announced it is deploying a self-driving vehicle to distribute personal protective equipment including masks, gloves and sanitisers to residents and workers of a residential complex in Sharjah.

* As of 5th May, the UAE has conducted 1.3 million coronavirus tests, which were done by hospitals, specialist health centres and 14 drive-through testing centres.The test is available for free in healthcare facilities across the emirate for people who are showing signs or symptoms of COVID-19, as well as for the elderly, pregnant women, and those who have chronic diseases. In addition, more than 58 studies are being conducted in the UAE to understand the nature of Covid-19 and develop innovative treatments, as well as diagnostic devices and medical tools
*9 May: Abu Dhabi Police launches mobile coronavirus screening centre.
*The cost for stem cell treatment of critical coronavirus cases will be covered by the government. The treatment was administered in the UAE to 73 COVID-19 patients who have all been successfully treated and cured of the virus by inhaling the treatment into their lungs after it has been nebulized into a fine mist.
*A patent has been granted by the Ministry of Economy for the development of an innovative and promising treatment for COVID-19 infections using stem cells. The treatment was developed by a team of doctors and researchers at the Abu Dhabi Stem Cell Center, ADSCC, and involves extracting stem cells from the patient's own blood and reintroducing them after activating them.

* To combat the spread of Covid-19, a walk-through sanitising gate solution offering an automatic 360° disinfection barrier that kills 99.9 per cent of germs and viruses will be launched in UAE this month.

* 28 April: Mandatory Covid-19 test for all workers before reopening Abu Dhabi malls, facilities.

* 26 April: The Ministry of Health and Prevention, Abu Dhabi Health Authority and Dubai Health Authority have jointly launched an app named ALHOSN UAE, to serve as a reference on the pandemic.

* 24 April: Dubai Corporation for Ambulance Services has announced the launch of its Mobile Laboratory Unit (MLU), to provide free testing for the elderly and 'people of determination' at their homes.
*22 April: In order to strengthen the UAE's fight against COVID-19, three new field hospitals are currently under development. The field hospitals are located in Abu Dhabi and Dubai, and will provide a total of 3,400 additional hospital beds when completed. They are being constructed by Abu Dhabi's public health provider, the Abu Dhabi Health Services Company (Seha).

* 19 April: Mohammed Bin Rashid University of Medicine and Health Sciences (MBRU) has launched a hackathon for UAE residents to develop innovative solutions that could help contain the spread of the virus. The winners will win AED 50,000 as well as an award from Sandooq Al Watan offering a National Impact Grant of AED 25,000 for one winning solution to develop it into a start-up serving the community.

* Artificial intelligence is used to accelerate diagnoses, disseminate trusted information as well as detecting fraudulent insurance claims and accurately evaluating patient data in real time. SoftBank-backed AI company Automation Anywhere is offering free healthcare bots to help the industry manage increased workloads due to the pandemic.

* 18 April: The Department of Health
- Abu Dhabi (DoH) has launched a new innovative smartphone app named TraceCovid.

* 15 April: The Dubai World Trade Centre (DWTC) has been converted into a field hospital with a capacity to treat up to 3,000 COVID-19 patients. It is partially open with a capacity of 1,000 beds

* A smart helmet technology capable of monitoring infected people will be used by specialist police teams around the country.

* 26 March: The UAE Government launched a 'National Disinfection Programme'. Under the programme, most of the cities were locked down from 26 March to 5 April, including public facilities; public transport and streets were disinfected every night from 8pm to 6 am.

* The UAE conducted more than half a million COVID-19 tests across the country. 13 drive-through COVID-19 test centers are set up across the country.

* Implementation of self-isolation and quarantine programs for travelers coming from outside the country. A large COVID-19 detection and testing laboratory is set up in Masdar City, with significant processing and testing capabilities.

* Free mobile internet data while using health sector platform apps

* Postponing the renewal of the occupational health card for facilities under the supervision of the municipality, and extension by the Dubai Health Authority (DHA) of the validity of expired health cards for three months, starting from 24 March

* Launching "We're Here for You" service for members of the UAE's diplomatic missions abroad which aims to preserve their health and safety by implementing precautionary and preventive measures

* Launching 'Weqaya', an electronic platform specifically designed to raise public health awareness in UAE on COVID-19

* Launching the 'National Campaign for Mental Support' with the participation of more than 50 experts to help the UAE's residents overcome the psychological impact resulting from the spread of COVID-19

* Launching the "We Are Your Family
- Remote" initiative which seeks to reach senior UAE citizens and check on their psychological and social health

* Turning ExCeL London, the largest venue for exhibitions and conferences in London, into a temporary field hospital to combat COVID-19

* Sending critical medical supplies including more than 40 tons of medicines and test kits and 6 medical teams to Iran in coordination with the World Health Organization. The UAE has also sent medical aid to Malaysia, Colombia, Afghanistan, Kazakhstan and Italy.
column28:
* The Community Solidarity Fund Against COVID-19 was launched by the Islamic Affairs and Charitable Activities Department in Dubai to support the efforts in mitigating the health, economic and social repercussions of the current crisis.
*The Abu Dhabi Food Control Authority (Adfca) is expanding its new food safety programme for 3,400 small eateries in the emirate which cater daily to around 340,000 people who mostly belong to low
- and lower-middle income groups.
*The Emirates Red Crescent announced it is in the process of sponsoring and caring for the families of deceased individuals who died of COVID-19 complications.

* 30 April: Employers must adhere to Ministerial Decree No. 739 of 2016 concerning the protection of wages, as well as employment contracts signed by employers and employees, ensuring employee wages are safeguarded and paid on time via the Wages Protection System

* The UAE enacted a new regulation on March 26 that allows employers to make workers redundant but must still provide housing (if provided contractually) and allow the employee to transfer his or her visa to a new employer if a new position is found. It also allows the employer to temporarily reduce salaries or force employees to take paid or unpaid annual leave.
column31:
* 21 April: The Federal Tax Authority (FTA) has issued a directive, on an exceptional basis, extending to 28 May 2020 the deadline of submitting VAT returns and the payment of due tax for the tax period ended 31 March 2020, enabling taxable persons to meet their tax obligations without facing any difficulties.

* At the local level, governments of several emirates have introduced financial assistance measures. Measures taken by the government of Dubai include a refund of 20% of customs fees imposed on imported goods, cuts in municipality fees imposed on sales at hotels, and a 10% reduction in water and electricity bills. In addition, the government of Abu Dhabi has reduced or suspended various government fees and penalties and granted substantial rebates to lease payments for companies in the tourism, hospitality and entertainment sectors.

* Dubai's government is freezing all hiring and cutting administrative spending by at least 20% across departments. Capital spending is reduced by 50%. All government construction projects are delayed.
column34:
* In Abu Dhabi, 200 Dhm million will be refunded to restaurants, tourism and entertainment facilities, which constitutes 20% of rental value of commercial properties

* 27 April: The Dubai Airport Freezone Authority, DAFZA, launched a set of economic incentive packages to support companies based in the free zone.

* 25 April: Abu Dhabi Ports announced a relief package for its customers, including a three-month rent deferment for Q2, a freeze on late payment penalties and an exemption from Tawtheeq fees.

* Dubai Free Zones Council announced an economic stimulus package on 28 March to support Dubai's businesses. It includes five key elements: postponement of rent payments by a period of 6 months; facilitating installments for payments; refunding security deposits and guarantees; cancellation of fines for both companies and individuals; and permitting temporary contracts that allow the free movement of labour between companies operating in the free zones for the rest of the year. These advantages also benefit workers seeking better job opportunities, and those who have been granted unpaid leave by facilitating their re-employment in jobs in Dubai.

* On 24 March, the UAE government announced a comprehensive economic package of AED 16 billion (USD 4.36 billion) to mitigate the effects of the crisis and support business continuity. The measures aim at lowering the cost of doing businesses, namely by cutting labour charges and other fees of the Ministry of Economy, suspending collection of administrative fines, reducing work permit fees for companies with up to six registered employees, and granting businesses a 50% rebate on bank guarantees submitted for their employees.
column37: Information not available
column40: * Approving a number of procedures to support the stock market and bonds, namely extending the deadline of submitting the financial statements for 2019
column46:
*13 April: The Central Bank of UAE (CBUAE) has decided to reduce by half the reserves requirements for demand deposits for all banks, from 14% to 7%. The CBUAE also discussed a capital buffer relief for banks participating in the TESS programme, postponed the implementation of certain Basel III capital standards to 31 March 2021, and issued a new requirement for all banks to apply a prudential filter to IFRS 9 expected loss provisions.
*The Emirate of Dubai has borrowed 272 million USD from the private placement of Islamic bonds. It placed an eight-year sukuk with a 4.71% rate of return.
column47: Information not available
column48:
*Launch of "10 million meals", the country's largest food distribution drive. Building on contribution from private companies, foundations, eateries and individuals, the camapign aims to feed individuals and families financially affected by the Covid-19. The campaign exceeded 15 million meals.

* Extending residence permits expired on March 1st for a period of 3 months and waiving administrative fines on expired permits till the end of 2020

* Waiving administrative fines for violations of the services provided by the Federal Authority for Identity and Nationality starting on April 1, 2020

* Granting a temporary license to digital transaction technology within the notary public's works in order to help citizens and residents complete their judicial transactions

* Extending the validity of government services ending on March 1st, 2020 for a period of 3 months

* Approving the registration of vehicles without paying traffic fines or conducting technical examination of the vehicle

* Reducing electricity and water consumption bills for customers in the tourism, hospitality and trade sectors by 20% for a period of 3 months with a total amount of AED 86 million

* Postponing the collection of installments on service reconnection fees for shopping mall, retail shops, hotels and hotel apartments for a period of 6 months
column51:
* 11 May: The Abu Dhabi Department of Economic Development, ADDED, announced the launch of a strategic new digital service that will enable restaurants, tourism and entertainment facilities within the emirate to apply for a 20 percent refund on the annual rental value of their commercial property leases.
*The Ministry of Human Resources and Emiratisation, MoHRE, has conducted 560 inspection visits to measure compliance of private establishments with the precautionary measures against the spread of COVID-19, under the national program to support the stability of the labor market in the private sector. It has also called on private sector establishments to consider workers infected with COVID-19 as sick cases entitled to sick leave as per Federal Law No. 8 of 1980.

* UAE National Emergency Crisis and Disaster Management Authority (NCEMA) launched on 14 March 2020, the Business Continuity Readiness Guidelines for UAE Organisations in the event of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19 outbreak, as part of efforts to boost the nation's readiness and response to emergencies and to transfer the best international practices. The purpose of this guide is to demonstrate precautionary and preventive measures aiming to sustain business continuity for organisations.

* On 5 April 2020, UAE Ministry of Human Resources and Emiratisation announced that it is allowing again expatriate workers in the private sector to return to their home countries

* Publishing a list of e-shopping applications in the UAE, as an alternative for in-person shopping
column54:
* Medical aid was sent to Ethiopia, Bangladesh, Somalia, Mauritania, South Africa, Kyrgyzstan, Armenia, Pakistan, Nepal, India, Botswana, Guinea, Kenya, SIerra Leone, Niger, Albania, Gambia, Romania, Italy, Afghanistan, Congo, Sudan, Iraqi Kurdistan
*14 May: The Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai has issued directives to grant 10-year Golden Visas to 212 doctors of various specialisations working for the Dubai Health Authority, as a token of appreciation for their efforts in the fight against COVID-19

* 13 May: Arab Youth Centre launches first Arab Youth Hackathon to support development, combat COVID-19 impacts.

* 6 May: UAE activates 'remote inspection initiative' of electronic sales platforms, websites.

* The Executive Committee of the Bureau International des Expositions, BIE, has collectively agreed to recommend the postponement of Expo 2020 Dubai to 1st October 2021
- 31st March 2022.

* Dubai Future Foundation (DFF) has launched the “One Million Arab Coders” COVID-19 Hackathon to engage Arab coders from around the world to develop innovative solutions to challenges that have emerged due to the COVID-19 outbreak, such as access to healthcare services, education, social solidarity and supporting startups .
*A new report released by Dubai Future Foundation on Wednesday, April 15, called for reassessing the existing telecom infrastructure needs, possible future regulatory changes and liberalisation of VPN and VoIP in the UAE and wider Mena region in the wake of massive increase in online traffic due to remote working policies and online streaming services.

* The UAE has joined a joint ministerial statement issued by several countries around the world, expressing their commitment to keeping the supply chains open in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. The initiative by New Zealand and Singapore stipulates that the signatory countries pledge their commitment to ensuring the continuity and interconnectivity of supply chains during the pandemic crisis and intensify joint efforts and coordination to identify and remove trade restrictive measures that negatively impact the movement of necessary goods.
*3 May: Abu Dhabi Ports signs virtual declaration to keep east-west trade open amid pandemic, joining 19 of the world's leading port authorities in a first-of-its-kind virtual declaration. Hosted via video conference, the Ports Authorities Roundtable, PAR, Declaration calls on member ports to work together by allowing merchant ships to berth and carry out cargo operations to maintain the global supply chain.

* Emirates has consolidated its waiver and refund policies into one unified procedure worldwide. As a part of this revamped travel system, the Dubai-based carrier is offering three option; 1. Keep the ticket, 2. Get a travel voucher, 3. Refund.

* In Dubai, drones were launched to monitor gatherings and disseminate warnings asking the public to stay home and avoid gatherings. Integrated, self-service and automated smart police stations were also set up, offering the same service as in traditional police stations

* Launching disinfection robots to contribute to the national sterilization program

* Issuing judicial legislation criminalizing the publication of rumors and the spread of false news during the crisis

* In addition to a dedicated National Strategy for Food Security and increasing the reserve of the Strategic Stock of Food Commodities by 30% (worth more than AED 500 million), the Emirates Food Security Council took measures to ensure food security, including :
1. Control systems to monitor food imports and track the movement of goods and basic food products along the supply chain which includes three stages: logistical movements on border crossings; Global Food Balance Sheet, which tracks the amounts of food available for supply and export to international markets; and early tracking of agricultural production via the Agricultural Market Information System.
2. Providing a flexible framework for procedures relating to implementing complementary standards, clearing food shipments using electronic health certificates and completing pesticide residue tests in the country.
3. Drawing a plan to diversify sources of imported basic food items in order to ease the food trade activities. The plan also tracks available logistical services in these new markets, and weighs the possibility of providing special flights, if necessary, in coordination with national air carriers to import certain goods.
4. Exploring ways to upgrade the UAE's local production capacities and provide government supply contracts through Abu Dhabi Agriculture and Food Safety Authority.
5. Coordinating with the Food Security Alliance to assess its readiness to support the national food security plans through its agricultural projects and available supplies.
6. Forming an Evaluation and Monitoring Team to follow up on any changes or developments and provide practical solutions and recommendations to the council. The team also addressed the logistical challenges on border crossings caused by to travel ban.
7. Developing a media awareness campaign to urge the public not to be swayed by rumors calling for excessive buying of food products, and to follow the advised precautionary measures to ensure food safety.

column12:
* Economy-wide lockdown since 23 March.

* The government announced a gradual easing of restrictions in England on 13 May, starting with the opening of most sectors that were closed during the lockdown, with the exception of entertainment, hospitality, and non-essential retail. There will be some relaxation of stay-at-home measures and unlimited exercise and driving to a national park or beach will be permitted. People can also see others from outside their household. If the health situation remains under control, a second phase would see the reopening of non-essential retailers and primary schools on 1 June, followed by the hospitality and entertainment sectors on 4 July.

* A new five-tier alert system on the status of the health crisis will be established to inform about further easing of restrictions, or their re-imposition. A Joint Biosecurity Centre will provide real-time analysis of local developments.

* Northern Ireland, Wales and Scotland are expected to announce their opening strategies soon.
column14:
* Borders remain open. People, trade and capital can enter and exit the country. The government advised British tourists currently abroad to return to the country, and advised against all non-essential travel worldwide.

* From 8 June, a 14-day quarantine period for all travellers coming to the UK will be in place. Travelers from the Republic of Ireland and freight drivers from France will be exempted.
column16:
* Schools are closed except for children of key workers (16 March).

* Primary schools re-opened on 1 June (11 May).
column18: * On 11 May, the government announced that outdoor places will reopen on 13 May and that people can exercise more than once a day. Social distancing measures remain in place. Ban on public events and social gatherings remains in place.
column20: * The government announced its opening strategy on 11 May. In a first phase, sectors that were closed during the lockdown can re-open again on 13 May, except entertainment, hospitality, and non-essential retail. All workers who cannot work from home should travel to work if their workplace is open. If the health situation remains under control, a second phase would see the reopening of non-essential retailers on 1 June, followed by the hospitality and entertainment sectors on 4 July.
column22: The UK government has announced a GBP 490 billion economic package (22.2% of GDP) to counter the impacts of coronavirus. This includes over GBP 330 billion (14.9% of GDP) of state loans and guarantees for struggling businesses, through the Coronavirus Corporate Financing Facility (20 March) and the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme (17 March). VAT payments of around GBP 30 billion (1.4% of GDP) for the second quarter of 2020 are deferred until 2021 (20 March). There is also GBP 130 billion (5.9% of GDP) of discretionary spending. This includes GBP 17.3 billion to support the NHS and other public services, GBP 30 billion for business support, and GBP 8 billion for welfare support. In addition, the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme and the Self-Employed Income Support Scheme are estimated to add around GBP 75 billion.
column25:
* GBP 17.3 billion for the National Health Service (NHS) and other public services to tackle the virus (4 June).

* On 11 May, the Government has committed to increase testing capacity to 200,000 tests per day by the end of May.

* The government advises citizens and international travellers to download and use the NHS contact tracing app.
column28:
* Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (20 March): For the next three months, all employers are eligible to apply for a grant to cover 80% of retained workers' salaries of up to GBP 2,500 a month. According to the OBR, the budgetary costs of the scheme are estimated at GBP 60 billion if take up is around 30% among private sector employees over four and a half months. On 12 May, the government announced to extend the job retention scheme until the end of October 2020 to avoid a cliff-edge withdrawal of wage support. Between August and October, 80% of wages of furloughed staff working part-time will be covered as well. Also starting in August, employers will share the costs of the job retention scheme, which would continue to receive the same 80 per cent of their salary. The government will announce further details on cost-sharing by the end of May.

* Self-employment Income Support Scheme (26 March): Provides self-employed a taxable grant of up to 80% of their previous earnings over the last three years (capped at GBP 2,500 a month and open for self-employed with average profits of less than GBP 50,000). The first grants will be paid in June and the scheme will run for at least three months. It will add around 15 billion to public debt if take up is around 2 million self-employed (or 40% of self-employed) over three months, according to the OBR.
An additional 8 billion in welfare spending, including:

* Universal Credit (UC) for self-employed (20 March): Suspension of the minimum income floor of UC, which the government uses to test whether it considers a person, who is not in employment, to be in gainful self-employment. Increase in the UC allowance by GBP 1,000 for the next twelve months.

* Statutory sick pay (SSP) for self-quarantined people (11 March) from the first day of absence rather than the fourth day as was previously the case.

* The government will reimburse up to 2 million SMEs for part of their SSP costs (GBP 2 billion).
column31:
* Deferral of income tax: Individuals who are due to pay their personal income tax under 'Self-Assessment', which would otherwise be due on 31 July 2020, will have the right to defer such payment until 31 January 2021 without interest or penalties.

* Waiving of custom duties and VAT tax on medical imports from outside the EU, including ventilators, testing kits and protective clothing in order to improve the delivery of critical medical supplies (31 March)
column34:
GBP 30 billion (1.4% of GDP) of support for businesses (11 March), including:

* the GBP 15 billion small business grant scheme with one-off cash grants between GBP 10,000 and GBP 25,000 for business with a property used for retail, hospitality or leisure (depending on the value of their properties but at a rateable value below GBP 51,000). This includes 12 billion in grants for England, and 3 billion for the devolved administrations so they can provide support to businesses in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

* Suspension of business rates for affected businesses (estimated to cost GBP 13 billion) (11 March).

* Refund of the cost of statutory sick leave up to 2 weeks for small businesses with less than 250 employees at a cost of GBP 1 billion (11 March).

* GBP 750 million grants and loans for business R&D through Innovate UK
column37:
* Deferral of VAT and self-assessed income tax payments of around GBP 30 billion (1.4% of GDP) for the second quarter of 2020 until 2021 (20 March)
'
* Businesses and self-employed people will also be able to negotiate bespoke 'Time to Pay' arrangements with HMRC in the event that they may otherwise struggle, or need more time, to pay their taxes (11 March).
column40:
* In a move to bolster high-tech start-ups, the new GBP 500 million Future Fund provides between 125k and 5m for UK based-business as long as the cash is matched by private investors (i.e. government is committing 250 million, with the other 250 million expected to be raised by the private sector). Start-ups must have previously raised at least 250k from private within the last 5 years investors to be eligible. The scheme will be launched in May, is initially open until September and will be delivered by the British Business Bank (20 April). If the government loan is not repaid within three years, it gets automatically converted into an equity stake at 20 percent discount to the valuation set in the next founding round.

* Smaller businesses focused on R&D can also apply for an additional GBP 750 million in grants and loans (20 April).
column43: * GBP 330 billion (14.9% of GDP) of temporary state loans and guarantee scheme for businesses. This includes the Coronavirus Corporate Financing Facility (20 March) and the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme (CBILS) (17 March). CBILS provides a partial government-backed guarantee for the loan repayments to encourage more lending. It will back loans of up to GBP 5 million for small and medium-sized businesses. No personal guarantees are required for facilities under GBP 250,000 and the government covers the first 12 months of interest payments and any lender-levied charges. In addition, the Coronavirus Large Business Interruption Loan Scheme (CLBILS) will provide a government guarantee of 80% to enable banks to make loans of up to GBP 25 million to larger firms with an annual turnover of between GBP 45 million and GBP 500 million (30 March). Loans backed by a guarantee under CLBILS will be offered at commercial rates of interest.
column46:
* Policy rate reductions: From 0.75% to 0.1% in two steps on 11 and 19 March.

* Lending support: The Covid Corporate Financing Facility (CCFF) provided jointly with the Treasury (17 March): Provides lending to businesses with minimum amount GBP 1 million per participant. The BoE will purchase commercial papers of firms of up to one-year maturity, with interest rate set with a fixed spread to the sterling overnight index swap (OIS) rate. The spread is determined based on rating or equivalent assessment. The scheme will operate for at least 12 months and will be financed by the issuance of central bank reserves.

* Liquidity support:

- Direct central bank financing of government debt through lifting of the GBP 370 million cap on the government's Ways and Means (W&M) facility (government's overdraft account with the BoE) to facility to directly finance additional government spending (9 April).

- Quantitative easing: Increase of BoE's holdings of UK government and corporate bonds by GBP 200 billion to a total of GBP 645 billion, financed by central bank reserves (19 March).

- The Term Funding scheme for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (TFSME) (11 March): Funding for banks will be provided at interest rates close to the Bank Rate of 0.1%, with lending to SMEs incentivised. Initially envisaged at a size of GBP 100 billion in 2020 (5% of GDP), the BoE recognised on 20 March that additional funding would be required.
column47:
* Macroprudential policies:

- Easing of capital requirements (17 March): The countercyclical capital buffer rate was cut to 0%, which is expected to support the ability of banks to supply additional credit of around GBP 190 billion.

- The Prudential Regulation Authority set out expectations that banks should not increase dividends or bonuses in response to the BoE's policy actions (17 March).
column54:
* Furloughed UK employees receiving benefits under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme are cleared to undertake extra work (8 April)

* Competition authorities softened rules that inhibit co-operation between supermarkets to permit sharing of data and distribution depots (20 March).
column55:
* Bank of England (2020), Bank of England measures to respond to the economic shock from Covid-19 (webpage), available at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2020/march/boe-measures-to-respond-to-the-economic-shock-from-covid-19 (11 March 2020).

* Bank of England (2020), HM Treasury and the Bank of England launch a Covid Corporate Financing Facility (CCFF) (webpage), https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2020/march/hmt-and-boe-launch-a-covid-corporate-financing-facility (17 March 2020).

* Bank of England (2020), Monetary Policy Summary for the special Monetary Policy Committee meeting on 19 March 2020 (webpage), available at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2020/monetary-policy-summary-for-the-special-monetary-policy-committee-meeting-on-19-march-2020 (19 March 2020)

* Bank of England (2020), HM Treasury and Bank of England announce temporary extension to Ways and Means facility (webpage), available at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2020/april/hmt-and-boe-announce-temporary-extension-to-ways-and-means-facility (9 April 2020).

* Financial Times (2020), Furloughed UK employees cleared to undertake extra work (webpage), available at https://www.ft.com/content/b03adf5c-b829-42ac-9a68-ca05938f4059 (8 April 2020).

* HM Treasury (2020), Budget 2020 (webpage), available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/budget-2020-documents/budget-2020 (12 March 2020)

* HM Treasury (2020), Chancellor waives duties and VAT on vital medical imports (webpage), available at https://www.gov.uk/government/news/chancellor-waives-duties-and-vat-on-vital-medical-imports (31 March 2020).

* HM Treasury (2020), Chancellor strengthens support on offer for business as first government-backed loans reach firms in need (webpage), available at https://www.gov.uk/government/news/chancellor-strengthens-support-on-offer-for-business-as-first-government-backed-loans-reach-firms-in-need (3 April 2020).

* HM Treasury (2020), HM Treasury and Bank of England announce temporary extension of the Ways and Means Facility (webpage), https://www.gov.uk/government/news/hm-treasury-and-bank-of-england-announce-temporary-extension-of-the-ways-and-means-facility (9 April 2020).

* HM Treasury (2020), Future Fund Headline Terms (webpage), available at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/880119/Convertible_Loan_Key_Terms_-__Final_Version_.pdf (25 April 2020).
Cabinet Office (2020), Our plan to rebuild: The UK Government's COVID-19 recovery strategy, available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/our-plan-to-rebuild-the-uk-governments-covid-19-recovery-strategy/our-plan-to-rebuild-the-uk-governments-covid-19-recovery-strategy#fourteen-supporting-programmes (12 May 2020).
HM Treasury (2020), Chancellor extends furlough scheme until October (webpage), available at https://www.gov.uk/government/news/chancellor-extends-furlough-scheme-until-october (accessed on 12 May 2020).

column12: 2 states have stay at home orders in place; 32 states have issued stay at home guidance
column14: On 11 March, all foreign nationals on flights from China, Iran and Europe are barred entry. On May 24 foreign nationals who had been in Brazil during 14 days preceding attempted entry to the United States were barred entry. American nationals visiting these places must return to designated
column16: schools have been closed in 44 states and recommended to be closed in a further 7 states
column18: 37 states have restrictions on the size of gatherings
column20: 42 states have some restrictions on businesses
column22: Congress passed an emergency $8.3billion spending bill and a subsequent bill that is assumed to be worth $108 billion. The CARES Act will have total cost of around $2 trillion or 9% of GDP. The Paycheck Protection Program and Health Care Enhancement Act approprated an additional $484 billion (2% of GDP).
column24: Congress bills amount to approximately $2.5 trillion
column25: Of the emergency package $3 billion was for research (vaccine), over 2$billion for prevention and response and $1billion for medical supplies
column28:
The Families First Coronavirus Response Act
- was largely targeted to support workers and social assistance. The bill provides for free testing for the coronavirus, 2weeks paid sick leave (capped) and then additional paid sick leave for workers with children for up to 3months. Additional resources were devoted to providing food for households with low income. Money was also targeted to support the expected increase of unemployment insurance, which is administered by the states. The bill also increases Medicaid payments to states.
column31: Congress passed the CARES Act that provides support for households and businesses during the crisis. The principle measures for busineses include:
column34: As part of the CARES Act, airlines, air cargo, and support firms will receive grants of $25 billion, $4 billion, and $3 billion, respectively, to maintain employment levels through September 30, 2020.
column37: The Treasury will defer tax payments without interest or penalties with the aim of shoring up liquidity.
column40: Announced measures instructed the Small Business Administration to use emergency power to provide capital and liquidity to firms affected by coronavirus. The Small Business Administration will offer low-interest federal disaster loans for working capital to small businesses suffering substantial economic injury as a result of the Coronavirus (COVID-19). A request of €50 billion (around 0.25% of GDP) will be made to Congress to provide low interest loans.
column46:
The FOMC lowered interest rates 100 basis points to 0-0.25%
The Federal Reserve resumed large scale asset purchases with the purchases of treasury securities and agency mortgage backed securities will be unlimited. The federal reserve has also announced the intention to revive the programmes from the great financial crisis that will allow it to purchase assets backed by student, car and credit-card loans, as well as loans to businesses through the Small Business Administration. Furthmore, a new programme lending directly to small business will be introduced.
column47:
The Federal Reserve has introduced a suite of measures to prevent credit markets seizing up. This includes pumping liquidity into the reserve purchase market, putting in place funding facilities (for commercial paper, primary dealers and money market mutal funds), actively intervening in bond markets (including municipal bond markets which have been stressed), reducing reserve requirements, relaxing caital buffers and encouraging big banks to use the deposit window.

The Federal Reserve has established temporary dollar liquidity arrangements (swap lines) with a number of other central banks. These are designed to reduce strains in dollar funding markets and thereby ease resulting strains on the supply of credit to households and businesses, both domestically and abroad.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development have imposed a 60 day morintorium on evictions and foreclosures for single family homeowners with Federal Housing Administration insured mortgages.
column54: Information not available

column12:
* The state of national sanitary emergency remains in force. A quarantine of at least 14 days continues to be in force for risk groups [since March 13].

* Preventive quarantine for individuals over 65 years old was introduced [since March 24].

* Intensified patrolling continues in order to avoid and discourage crowds [since March 31].

* The practice of eight outdoor sports was enabled, with some measures of physical distance and without the use of masks [announced on May 15].
column14: * Border closure remains in force. Only Uruguayan citizens and foreign residents are authorized to enter the country. Only the two main international airports will continue to operate. The transport of goods, merchandise, correspondence, supplies and humanitarian aid are exempt [since March 13].
column16: * Second phase of face-to-face and voluntary return to classes starts from June 15. Second phase includes the return to school of early childhood and initial education centres across the country. All primary schools, lyceums, and technical training, both intermediate and tertiary, are reopened, except in Montevideo and the metropolitan area. In Montevideo and the metropolitan area, only the last year of upper secondary education (baccalaureate) of Secondary and UTU is reopened. The last year of training in education is reopened throughout the country. Rural, special and vulnerable schools remain to be open. Third phase of return to classes is expected to start on June 29. All schools remain open to provide meals to vulnerable students.
column18:
* Cancellation of public events and events involving the agglomeration of people remains in force [since March 13].

* Temporary closure of public parks and other recreational spaces remains in force [since March 31].
column20:
* Non-mandatory recommendation of working from home. The construction sector continues work activity.

* The govt. published a mandatory protocol for the reopening of economic activities. It covers the activities of commerce, retail food, hotels, restaurants and bars, and professional, technical and specialized services. It establishes the obligation to have alcohol in gel, a minimum distance of one and a half meters between people, the use of face masks to enter the premises and disinfection of hygienic services, among others [announced on May 15].
column22: * COVID-19 Fund was created to finance measures of up to USD 400 million (0.8% GDP). This Fund will be financed by public resources, utilities from state-owned enterprises and a Covid-19 emergency health tax which will be applied to the salaries and pensions of public servants earning more than URY 120 000 during two months.
column25:
* In order to prevent price gouging, a list of prices of basic sanitary products was published since April 17.

* Free service for medical consultation by phone since April 13.

* The facilities of the Spanish Hospital start to be conditioned to turn it into the first COVID-19 centre. A public-private partnership to develop the Coronavirus.uy application. A call by the National Research and Innovation Agency for the development of a COVID-19 fast diagnostic kit
- 80% of the project, for a maximum amount of URY 6 million, would be financed by the state. Sponsoring a collaboration between researchers form the Universidad de la Republica and the Pasteur Institute to develop molecular diagnostic techniques to detect COVID-19. Creation of a programme to host homeless people over 65 years old [since March 16].
column28:
* During June and July, the govt. will continue to double the amounts of the Uruguay Social card and the Equity Plan family allowance. Additionally, it transformed the Uruguay Works programme, enabled more places in shelters for people on the street, and plans to deliver 5,000 food baskets in Rivera, where a dining room opened for 500 diners [announced on May 27].

* A special COVID-unemployment insurance and partial insurance was created. Initiatives include (i) subsidies for self-employed for two months (URY 6 800 per month for 10 000 self-employed); (ii) a food basket for family members receiving social benefits; and (iii) free Internet access for 120 000 households. Plus, (iv) individuals who rent with the guarantee of the General Accounting Office of the Nation (CGN) will receive a direct support from the state for the 50% of their rent and a subsidy for the other 50%, (v) April mortgage loan instalments will be reduced to 50% and the remaining balance will be passed to the end of the loan interest-free. At the same time, individuals who cannot pay for the April fee (50%) will not be finned or surcharged for 180 days.

* A sickness subsidy will be granted to all private sector wage workers over 65 years old to ensure they comply with their quarantine [since March 25].

* The govt. announced a relaxation of the unemployment insurance conditions to benefit more workers affected by COVID-19. The measure will cover monthly workers with between 3 and 5 months of contributions in the last year and day laborers with between 75 and 149 days. Teaching, cultural and sports workers may also access the insurance [announced on May 8].

* The govt. announced the extension, until July 31, of the partial unemployment insurance [announced on June 12].
column31:
* The Covid-19 emergency health tax on the salaries and pensions of public servants earning more than URY 120 000 (5%, 10%, 15%, or 20% depending on the salary) remains in force.

* The govt. announced a two-month extension of the subsidy for 10,000 MIDES monotributistas. This subsidy, of about 6,800 pesos, covers the most vulnerable workers [announced on June 12].
column34:
* The Central Bank (BCU), through the Superintendency of Financial Services, authorized banks, financial services companies and credit management companies to extend the maturity of loans to the non-financial sector in agreement with their clients for up to 180 days.

* The fund that guarantees loans for SMEs will be expanded from US$50 million to US$500 million with international organizations financing. That will allow to guarantee the SME loans totalling US$2.5 billion. In addition, the rate of commission charged by the fund will be reduced substantially.

* The government-owned Banco Republica (BROU), the country's largest commercial bank, will extend soft loans -with lower interest rates, longer terms and even grace periods
- to enterprises.

* In addition, direct credit program for micro and small enterprises will extend working capital loans of up to 18 months to the affected businesses at subsidized rates. Loan repayments for these enterprises are being suspended for at least 30 days.

* The National Development Agency (ANDE) will grant special benefits to 67 000 own-account workers with soft loans of URY 12 000.
column37:
* Income tax payments of small companies corresponding to the months of February and March have been deferred.

* The minimum VAT payments corresponding to the months of February and March have been deferred.

* Employer's social security mandatory payments will been postponed during March and April for own-account workers and employers with up to 10 employees that participate of the Industry and Trade regime. Employers will be able to pay them without interest in six equal, consecutive, monthly instalments as from June. Property taxes will be reduced for the Agriculture sector.

* The deadline foreseen for those entities obliged to submit their Financial Statements to the Internal Audit of the Nation, and whose maturity occurs between March 13 and May 15, 2020, is suspended [announced on April 13].
column40: * The govt. launched a credit program to grant liquidity to one-person companies. It will offer a loan for 12,000 pesos in May and 12,000 pesos in June, it will not charge an interest rate and is be paid in 24 equal and consecutive installments [announced on May 4].
column46: * The Central Bank temporarily reduced the reserve requirements for commercial banks.
column47: Information not available
column51: * Suspension of outages for non-payment of electricity supply (users of general and residential plans) and telecommunications services (residential and business users of certain sectors) [since April 6].
column54: * To contain the nutritional risk in the most vulnerable population, the National Meat Institute (INAC) delivered 8,000 kilograms of meat to the National Food Institute that will be distributed between May and September. The National System of Community Canteens serves 17,000 people on a daily basis. During this period, 17 departments will be supplied with sheep, poultry and pork.

column12:
* From 13 February to 4 March, restrictions on incoming and outgoing travel from the commune of Son Loi with a population of 10,000.

* On 27 March, social distancing measures stepped up (Directive 15): banning gatherings of more than 10 people, except those in offices, schools and hospitals; religious gatherings with more than 20 people also banned from 28 March to 15 April.

* From 1 April to 15 April, nation-wide social distancing campaign implemented (Directive 16, announced on 31 March): including banning of gatherings of more than two people, confinement at home with some exceptions and closure of non-essential services.

* On 15 April, extension of social distancing for at least one week in "high-risk" and "risky" localities (Hanoi, HCMC and 10 other cities) until 22 April. Social distancing measures loosened in other areas of the country allowing some industries and businesses to resume operations from April 16.

* On, 22 April, social distancing measures based on Directive 16 ended, replaced by Directive 15 from 23 April except for some smaller districts.

* On April 25, Directive No. 19 issued, banning religious gatherings, festivals, and sporting events and continued closure of bars, pubs, beauty salons, and karaoke bars until further notice.
column14:
* From 23 January, suspension of passenger train services between Viet Nam and China.

* On 28 January, the Ministry of National Defense to close trails connecting to China and to step up border control.

* On 30 January, Viet Nam stopped issuing entry visa for foreign visitors who have visited mainland China.

* On 1 February, the civil aviation authority suspended all flights to mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Chinese Taipei.

* From 25 February, the Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs halted sending overseas Vietnamese workers to infected countries.

* On 9 March, tightened entry restrictions, stopped issuing tourist visas to visitors from Schengen countries, the UK and some US states, permitted travel to business and diplomatic entries, but only after submission of a health certificate/questionnaire.

* From 21 March, all foreign visitors from infected countries are quarantined for two weeks.

* From 18 March visa issuance to foreign visitors suspended for 30 days except for some specific cases, such as diplomats/officials.

* From 23 March, all international flights suspended until the end of April, except for those repatriating Vietnamese nationals.

* On 27 March, Ministry of Transport reduced flights from Ha Noi and Ho Chi Minh City to other localities, temporarily suspended or limited public transport, except for vehicles for goods transportation. Inter-regional public transport services minimised except for essential services.

* On 1 April, the reduction and halt of domestic public transportation services.

* From 1 April to 15 April, temporary closure of Viet Nam
- Cambodia and Viet Nam
- Lao PDR border crossings.

* On 23 April, the restrictions on low-risk domestic public transportation eased.

* From 12 May, partial border gate opening between China, only for trade of agriculture goods and parts and raw materials for manufacturing.

* On 21 May, the Ministry of Transportation instructed the Civial Aviation Authority to submit by 10 June, a plan for the gradual lifting of the ban on international flights.
column16:
* On 3 February, Ministry of Education and Training requested to keep schools closed nationwide after the Lunar New Year (25 January) holiday (beginning of February 2020).

* On 20 April, the northern province of Thai Binh and the Mekong Delta province of Ca Mau were the to let students return to schools. Reopened schools split classes into smaller groups and implemented measures to maintain a safe distance of two metres between parents waiting to pick up their children.

* From 27 April, 30 provinces are allowed to resume classes.

* On 4 May, middle and high schools in major cities resumed classes, while kindergarten and elementary schools will return on May 11.
column18:
* On 3 February, localities that have declared outbreaks of Covid-19 requested to halt all festivals.

* On 27 March, social distancing measures stepped up (Directive 15): gatherings of more than 10 people banned, except those in offices, schools and hospitals; all cultural, sports and entertainment activities at public places, and religious rituals of more than 20 people were banned from 28 March to 15 April. Closure of non-essential businesses like bars, night clubs, movie theaters, and karaoke bars until May 4.

* From 1 April to 15 April, a nation-wide social distancing campaign implemented (Directive 16, announced on 31 March): including banning of gatherings of more than two people, confinement at home with exception and closure of non-essential services.

* On 15 April, extension of social distancing for at least one week in "high-risk" and "risky" localities (Hanoi, HCMC and 10 other cities) until 22 April. Social distancing measures relaxed in other areas of the country allowing some industries and businesses to resume operations from April 16.

* On, 22 April, the social distancing measures of Directive 16 lifted and replaced by Directive 15 from 23 April except for some smaller districts.

* On April 25, Directive No. 19 banned religious gatherings, festivals, and sporting events and continued closure of bars, pubs, beauty salons, and karaoke bars until further notice.
column20:
* On 15 March, Ho Chi Minh City closed down movie theaters and karaoke bars.

* On 15 March, Hai Phong City closed down entertainment venues including discos, karaoke bars, saunas, massage parlors, bars, internet cafés, golf courses, and tourist attractions until the end of March.

* From 1 April to 15 April, nation-wide social distancing campaign implemented (Directive 16, announced on 31 March): including banning of gatherings of more than two people, confinement at home with exception and closure of non-essential services.

* On 15 April, extension of social distancing for at least one week in "high-risk" and "risky" localities (Hanoi, HCMC and 10 other cities) until 22 April. Social distancing measures were relaxed in other areas of the country allowing some industries and businesses to resume operations from April 16.

* On, 22 April, the social distancing measures of Directive 16 were lifted and replaced by Directive 15 from 23 April except for some small districts.

* On April 25, Directive No. 19 issued, banning religious gatherings, festivals, and sporting events and continued closure of bars, pubs, beauty salons, and karaoke bars until further notice.
column22:
* On 6 March, mitigation measures announced, including requests to financial institutions to facilitate credit access, shorten loan applications, and reduce/exempt interest rates for affected customers, deferment of tax payments for 5 months. No budget allocation is involved.

* On 18 March, reduction of services fees by 10%-50% for nine categories of stock market transactions and fee-waiver for six other services, until 31 August 2020, and extended if needed.

* On 8 April, Government Decree No 41/2020/ND-CP promised a five-month payment deferral for tax and land use fees worth VND 180 trillion (7.7 billion USD). Under the draft, the deferral could be prolonged by up to one year

* On 10 April, approval of an additional relief package amounting to VND 62 trillion, including cash handout to 20 million people and zero-interest loans to employers for salaries.
column25:
* On 30 January, the National Steering Committee on Covid 19 and the Emergency Taskforce established to assist the PM in directing ministries, agencies and localities to prevent and control the epidemic and to communicate pertinent information to citizens.

* On 8 February, the Ministry of Health launched website to share official information on Covid-19, and act as the health sector's main channel to provide official information on guidelines and activities of the health sector, assistance information, and instructions on disease prevention.

* On 20 April, the Ministry of Information and Communications launched a remote medical examination and treatment platform and Bluezone app designed to support remote hospitals for medical examination and treatment, including Covid-19.
column28:
* On 10 April, 2020, resolution 42/NQ-CP approved a support measure worth VND 62 trillion (2.66 billion USD) to support people from April to June, and firms affected by Covid-19 during this period. A total of 20 million people will benefit with VND 500,000 for contributors to the revolution and nation building, VND 1 million for household around poverty line or below, VND 1.8 million for employees who take unpaid leave for more than 14 days, VND 1 million to workers who do not benefit from unemployment insurance, and VND 1 million to self-employed with income less than VND 100 million. VND 36 trillion will come from state budget, VND 22 to 23 trillion from local budget, with the rest from pension fund, deferment of unemployment insurance contribution, unemployment insurance fund.

* On 13 April, the Ministry of Industry and Trade cut electricity bills for businesses and households by 10 percent for three months.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37:
* On 11 March, the Ministry of Finance submitted a measure to defer tax payment (personal and corporate tax, including value-added tax, income tax, land lease) by five months for certain sectors, for a total of VND 30 trillion.

* On 15 March, the Ministry of Labor-Invalids and Social Affair gave permission to firms to request late payment of social security contributions.

* On 26 March, the Ministry of Finance submitted a draft legislation to defer tax payment of five months for firms and self-employed for a total of VND 80.2 trillion, of which VND 61.6 trillion for VAT, VND 11.1 trillion of corporate income tax, VND 3 trillion of income tax for self-employed, VND 4.5 trillion of land lease.

* On 8 April, Resolution 41 deferred tax payment (VAT, corporate and personal income tax, land lease) by 5 months without penalty.

* On 21 April, Ho Chi Minh City requested the deferral of tax and land lease payment to the tax authority, and the deferral of social security contribution payment to social security offices.
column40: * On 10 April, 2020, Resolution 42/NQ-CP approved a support measure worth VND 62 trillion (2.66 billion USD) to support people from April to June, and firms affected by Covid-19 during this period. Firms who have put employees to unpaid leave for three months, but cover at least 50% of the salary will be entitled to borrow from Viet Nam Bank for Social Policy (VBSP) at zero interest rate to cover the salary payment, backed by a VND 16 trillion of credit line to VBSP.
column46:
* On 16 March, the State Bank of Viet Nam decided to reduce its policy rate from 17 March. The refinancing rate, the most important policy rate, is now at 5.00 % down from 6.00 %. Other policy rates were also lowered (discount rate from 4.0% to 3.5%, overnight rate from 7.0% to 6.0%).

* On 13 May, the State Bank of Vietnam reduced the policy rates for a second time since the Covid-19 outbreak: refinancing rate reduced to 4.5% from 5%, discount rate to 3% from 3.5%.
column47: * On 12 March, the State Bank of Viet Nam issues a notice (effective 13 March, 01/2020/TT-NHNN) specifying conditions for extending repayment period and reducing interest rate.
column48: * On 21 April, Ho Chi Minh City requested public utility fees (electricity, water) to be reduced for its residents until the end of the year.
column51: * On 21 April, Ho Chi Minh City requested public utility fees (electricity, water) to be reduced for companies located in the city, until the end of the year.
column54:
* Since14 February, import tariff waived for masks, textile for marks, and hand-washing soap.

* On 8 April, the Ministry of Industry and Trade submitted a proposal for measures to support parts manufacturing industry affected by trade with China, to increase the domestic value-added, through increase in local content of auto parts, amendment of Special Consumption Tax and preferential-interest-loans for certain sectors.

* On 14 April, the Ministry of Finance announced a reduction of 20 kinds of fees related to securities exchange.
